title: spring into action!
content:
This is a typeface based on a video that I made on type that was created with a scrap of paper..video can be viewed here: [http://dada.cca.edu/~falfonso/vid/sound.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084102/http:/dada.cca.edu/~falfonso/vid/sound.htm "http://dada.cca.edu/~falfonso/vid/sound.htm") Nothing's done yet and any feed back would be much appreciated. Also, although I don't know anything about open type, I will be making an open typeface with lots of ligatures.

f

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [spring.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084102/http:/typophile.com/files/spring.gif) | 23.21 KB |
author: NotEgyptian

comments.content:
I think it has a lot of potential. It has a wonderful textural presence. I especially like the way the letters start to interact with each other. It needs more work, but has a start it good. It had some feeling of a script, without being a script typeface. The weights need to be more normalized and the addition of numerous ligatures could make it much more smooth and pleasing to view.

shu

I think i agree! It makes me think of what [Ralph Steadman](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084102/http:/www.ralphsteadman.com/) might come up with if he set about to design a font like [tension.](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084102/http:/www.t26.com/fonts/display.php?f_id=734) That said, keeping some of the ridiculous variation in weight within the individual glyphs but maybe going for more consistancy with this through the entire typeface might be a good direction.. (now that i've said that, i think i'm probably just re-iterating shu)

either way, i'm interested in seeing where you take it from here.

I may 3rd the 'Nice Start'.. :) I like the Uppercase.. The 'scribbley' / sketchy and naive nature of your type reminds me of ' [Fixogum](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084102/http:/www.ingofonts.com/)', by [Ingo Zimmermann](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084102/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Ingo%20Zimmermann)..

Dav, [formlos](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084102/http:/www.formlos.net/)
